title: Request for an unredacted copy of the SCC apology to the law courts, for creating false evidence, being untruthful in witness & wrongful omissions

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
At the meeting of the meeting of the Sheffield City Council (SCC) Strategy and Resources Policy Committee, on the 13th of December 2023, Councillor Tom Hunt - Council Leader and Committee Chairman (Labour) was asked whether or not Sheffield City Council had apologised to the courts of law for misleading and lying in court. A court of law was wronged by SCC on at least two occasions: in 2016 and in 2017. At paragraph 5.2, the minutes of the meeting record that Cllr Hunt responded as follows:
“I have been assured that the apology will be sent to the court before the end of this month. This will be made public and I have asked officers to notify you when this takes place.”
SOURCE (Item 5):
https://democracy.sheffield.gov.uk/docum...
https://ianswalkonthewildside.wordpress....
To date (1st January 2024), the SCC apology to the law courts has not been shared with the public or made publicly accessible.
Please provide a complete, unredacted copy of the SCC apology to the law courts. Please state:
1)	the authors of the apology;
2)	the date the apology was sent, in each case;
3)	the name and title of the addressee/s;
4)	the position held by the addressee/s.
To understand the basis for this request, and the strong level of public interest in the apology, see the comments associated with this request, below.
Yours faithfully,
Mr David Long

Dear Mr Long
Thank you for your request of 1 January 2024 regarding the council’s
apology to the court arising from Sir Mark Lowcock’s report on the Street
Tree Dispute on 6 March 2023.
Please find our response to your questions:
Please provide a complete, unredacted copy of the SCC apology to the law
courts.
Please note that this information is exempt from disclosure under section
22 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000 on the grounds that it is
information which is intended for future publication. The information was
already held with a view to such publication at the time when the request
for information was made and we consider that it is reasonable in all the
circumstances that the information should be withheld from disclosure to
ensure that it can be received by the judicial authorities first before it
is disclosed to the public.
Section 22 is a qualified exemption which is subject to the public
interest test. Factors in favour of disclosure are that disclosure
promotes openness and transparency. Factors in favour of maintaining the
exemption are that there is a public interest in ensuring that there is
time for the judicial system to consider the submission before it is made
public, and that the timetable properly requires due time for those
authorities prior to its public release. On balance, the Council believes
that the public interest lies in maintaining the exemption.
Please state:
1)      the authors of the apology;                                 David
Hollis, General Counsel and Kate Josephs, Chief Executive
2)      the date the apology was sent, in each case;      22 December 2023
3)      the name and title of the addressee/s;                Right
Honourable Alex Chalke KC MP
4)      the position held by the addressee/s.                  Lord
Chancellor and Secretary of State for Justice
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please pass this on to the person who conducts Freedom of Information reviews.
I am writing to request an internal review of Sheffield City Council's handling of my FOI request 'Request for an unredacted copy of the SCC apology to the law courts, for creating false evidence, being untruthful in witness & wrongful omissions'.
I believe the section 22 exemption of the Freedom of Information Act 2000 is being misused and abused by Sheffield City Council, to willfully obfuscate and withhold access to information that has been paid for by tax-payers and that is of public interest, as has happened previously, on many occasions, regarding access to documents associated with the £2.2bn 'Streets Ahead' highway maintenance project.
Save Our Roadside Trees (SORT: formerly Save Our Rustlings Trees), and myself, consider that it is reasonable, in light of all the circumstances of the case, that the information should NOT be withheld from disclosure, because such time as is reasonable has passed. One month has been sufficient time for for the communication to be received by the judicial system and authorities to consider the submission and for the Lord Chancellor’s office to respond.
We - SORT & I - KNOW that, on balance, it is NOT in the public interest for Sheffield City Council to maintain the exemption that it currently uses to obfuscate and deny access to the requested communication - a communication that should have been issued in the summer of 2023 (rather than at Christmas). See item 2, here:
https://ianswalkonthewildside.wordpress....
A full history of my FOI request and all correspondence is available on the Internet at this address:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/r...
Did the communication that I have requested include a request that the addressee respond to the communication? In total, how long is the period that Sheffield City Council is willing to permit for the provision of a response by the addressee?
Yours faithfully,
Mr Long

Dear Mr Long
We are partially upholding your complaint as a result of your request for
an internal review on 31 January 2024 regarding your request for a copy of
the council’s apology to the courts.
In withholding the exemption under Section 22 because the apology was
intended for future publication, we failed to give you our target date.
That date was 31 January 2024 and you have since received a link to the
apology, which is held in the Street Tree Archive here:
[1]
http://tinyurl.com/363wz3xy
Your request was received on 1 January 2024 and was due on 30 January
2024. Our apology was sent to the Lord Chancellor on 22 December 2023. We
provided a copy to senior members of the council on 4 January 2024. We
explained: It is our intention to publish this letter but at this stage
please treat as confidential, it is right that we await acknowledgement
that the Lord Chancellor’s office have received and noted that this will
be published before we share more widely.
We received confirmation of receipt on 18 January 2024. We then made
preparations for publication in our Street Tree Archive.
Our intention was always to publish on 31 January but the deadline for a
response to you fell the day before. Our final preparations were still
being made. We should have said publication was imminent. We apologise for
your frustration.
If you are still dissatisfied with the handling of your request, you can
ask the Information Commissioner for a decision: [2][

Dear SCC Information Officer,
Please would you attach the Sheffield City Council (SCC) apology as a PDF file, here, at whatdotheyknow, so that it can be download and saved.
You have informed that SCC received acknowledgement that the Lord Chancellor’s office had received and noted the SCC apology on the 18th of January 2024. WHY did you not provide the information requested at any point during the TWO WEEK PERIOD between 17/1/2024 and 31/1/2024?
It was clear that SCC had no objection to the information that I had requested being shared with me at any point during that period. See this e-mail from the SCC Chief Executive (Kate Josephs):

Dear Mr Long
The apology to the court was sent on Friday 22 December.  It has been sent to the Lord Chancellor who has overall administrative responsibility for all the Courts.
We have not published a copy at this stage.  As a matter of courtesy, we should let the Lord Chancellor receive and consider it before we make it public.  We have said in the apology letter that we intend to publish it. I WILL MAKE SURE YOU RECEIVE A COPY DIRECT WHEN WE HEAR BACK FROM THE LORD CHANCELLOR’S OFFICE.
I hope you have had a good Christmas break.
Regards
Kate
